did.unittitle: Union League of Philadelphia Member Relations Committee records

bioghist.p: The Union League of Philadelphia was founded in 1862 as a patriotic society to support the policies of President Abraham Lincoln. It evolved to its current identity as a non-sectarian and non-partisan private club. In an effort to boost declining membership, a Membership Development Committee was appointed in 1982. This Committee became a part of a newly established Standing Committee in 1988, Member Relations, which was responsible for: recruiting new members, facilitating assimilation of new members, monitoring member usage, targeting areas for improvement and enhancements to stem resignations, and encouraging spousal use. It also became responsible for oversight of Clubs Tables and all communications, including marketing, public relations, and the Bulletin/Banner. Its work overlapped with the Activities Committee through its encouragement of Club Tables as well as Junior member activities. The Banner was also the responsibility of Activities at one time, and also the House Committee. The House Committee shared some entertainment responsibilities with Member Relations. Member Relations worked closely with the Admissions Committee, which is separately appointed according to the By-Laws.

scopecontent.p: The series has been arranged into three subseries: General, Club Tables, and Bulletin/Banner. The Club Tables subseries consists primarily of information on the different club tables; the amount of documentation varies by club. These materials include correspondence, meeting minutes, printed announcements, member information and directories, attendance reports, financial records (such as bank statements, receipts, and reports), club histories, menus, and ephemera. The subseries also contains some information related to club tables in general, including statistics and announcements. The Member Relations subseries contains bound volumes of member directories, files dedicated to membership development (which include printed information about the Union League), an outside study looking at the communications of the Union League, some minutes, and committee memoranda. The Bulletin/Banner is a comprehensive run of the monthly publication from 1944 through May 2008.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
